div1.head: Notes on mosquito control, by [Henry Rose Carter?], [19--]
div1.p:
General Suggestions in Precautionary Measures for Preventing Prolific Anopheles
Production in Proposed Impounded Water Bodies-

{Preliminary Work to be
{Accomplished before
{Water Elevation is Raised

(1) Make map to scale of area to be covered & including
all houses within one mile of the contour line
of lake at time of maximum high water

(2) Include on Show on map in correct location all houses with names tenants
Rivers, creeks, ravines streams big & small & their branches, swamps,
seepage outcrops, ponds, pools, ditches that stay wet
soft bag lands; springs, wells & other wet places in which
mosquitoes might propagate, within the area to be flooded
and for one mile distant and parallel to the maximum
flood line contour- This is important-.

(3) Plot on map the contour line or lines of proposed
high, average & low flow lines allowed-.

(4) In places where land is flat or of gradual slope, show
such land on map by one foot contours-spaced one
so as to show slope; 1 ft or 2 ft contours-.

Denote on map by appropriate symbols for Spring, Summer,
and late Autumn the places & species of & date. Anopheles larvae occurrence
in all wet areas mentioned in paragraph # 2-.

Record several catches of Anopheles made at houses & outhouses
(particularly in barns & pigpens & under houses) at the height of
the anopheles production season- If such work is done for
two seasons, at various points both close to the main river
and a mile from the pond edge, the data might prove
of immense value at a future date-.

(7) Employ all physicians practicing in the neighborhood
within from one to several miles of the proposed
pond edge, to search their records & give names and
dates of malaria cases among their patients so far as
they have record or can remember with such note or
comment as they care to add-.

If possible take index of existing malaria rate, for 1 mile from river flow line supply
all tenants with & local physicians with printed matter
pertaining to malaria prevention,-

(8) Settle as far as possible all damage and land claims fairly before water
is turned on. Pay additional and just price for quiet
residence claims on residences in areas near inlets
that will be flooded & apparently become of sanitary
importance, or make written agreement for fixed sum
to be paid if they should turn out to be so-.

If at some future date flash boards might become
desirable for financial reasons, it is well to
purchase sufficient land above the heavy flood
line flow of the proposed lake, so as to allow for
the change and this will give room for raking out
debris & deposit of floatage.

(10) Purchase flat lands where the water table will
be raised so close to the ground surface as to damage
crops during wet seasons. It may become necessary
as a sanitary measure to keep stock off some fields
with ground water close to the surface as hoof
marks increase anopheles production- Land values
for purchasers often increase after water is impounded.

(11) At the mouths of small streams & ravines
toward the upper end of the pond, silt, sand &
gravel & debris often pile up & interfere with agricul-
tural operations or grazing value of lands & may
become anopheles production areas - it simplifies matters
for such lands to be transferred to the party using the
water power.

Proper fish control is most important tho not perfect.
Some ponds of impounded water have become so
thoroughly stocked with certain practically efficient top
feeding minnows as to make those ponds practically non-productive
of the species of Anopheles that convey malaria even where
bass, peckerel, & other game fish were present in fair numbers.
In one instance, this occurred in a pond over (a mile) ? Hartsville long
where the plantaquatic growth (water shield) extended almost
from shore to shore. During two years of inspection
of various lakes impounded by corporations for power purposes,
it has been noted that in those portions lakes where
the proper species of top feeding minnows were very
numerous in most instances anopheles larvae were
either relatively scarce (or of no sanitary importance), or were
absent- It is therefore evident that advantage should
be taken of these facts as early as possible after a
company get a franchise to impound water and
proper minnow propagation should lie in all cases be
started early, so as to have millionsthousands of them ready
to be liberated into the lake as soon as the impound
ing of water starts- In case large fish such as prey
5
on the top feeders are numerous, it might be well to
destroy those in the area to be covered by the lake
provided the consent of the proper authorities is
obtained with a written agreement that at a fixed
future date, say three years, the proper authorities
will restock the lake with game fish at the expense
of the owners of the water power plant. Such an
arrangement would enable the small top feeders to multiply
much more rapidly than under normal conditions. &
later increase the supply - of game fish-.

Small ponds might be made at the sides of streams
suitable topographically, and within the area to be flooded
and above it-. They should be so located as not to have
the fish washed out at time of freshets & arranged so that
minnows will thrive, multiply, & can not escape-.

Much harm wouldmight be done by stocking the lake
with the wrong kind of fish (ie) those that grow large
and eat top minnows-. Carp

12A Take proper preventive measures to keep the labor force at the
dam, power house, etc fairly free from malaria during period of
construction- Use mosquito control by drainage & oiling, efficient
protected screening with of 16 mesh, quinine control & bloold examination
Do not allow sale of harmful patent so called chill tonic at commissaries
It does not reduce malaria but often increases it-

Measures or Precautions to Prevent Ano Control prolific Anopheles Production
in Impounded water-

13 Clear all brush & brambles from inlets & ravines & hights that
would otherwise be left standing in the water
except that which will be completely & continuously
submerged at time of lowest water -- do the same
along the flow line of the lake -- where pile the
brush & burn it completely as soon as dry-. This work
can often be done most advantageously by contract
by the previous land owners & native labor -. Near the
water line all brush & saplings must be cut close to
the ground- It will be advantage out to make this
clearing for three to 5 feet above the high water mark line also - so as
to allow floatage to become stranded- On gentle slopes
more than five feet back-. All growth that might
reach over into the water should be removed-

Willow trees & others, whose tops are clustered &which we close together in narrow
will bodies of water & whose tops will pierce the
water line should be removed, especially when
near the shore line, or that part their tops removed
so the place where cut is made will remain
submerged-.

14 Cut down or ring all pine trees as early as possible
which are within or not far from the proposed
shore line to prevent pine tags collecting on the
water surface- Do not leave cut trees or piled
brush so it will be partially submerged at low
water. Burn up all loose trash that would other
wise become floatage-.

15 the clearing of growth on, below, or near the flow line
at upper end of all inlets should be thoroughly
performed and the work mentioned in paragraphs
13, 14, 15, should be inspected by a person having
a thorough knowledge of anopheles habits & production
in impounded waters before the water is turned on-
so that any additional necessary work can be finished
up at reasonable cost before the water rises & before
it is too late to do so economically-. Precautionary
measures for anopheles control undertaken after impounding
of water are less satisfactory & very expensive-.

Narrow strips of water between shorelines, with vegetation
at edges frequently harbour anopheles larvae & are more
protected from wind & wave action than are broad expanses
between shores- It may be necessary to give such areas
special treatment and is best to consider such places as
needing inspection until proved to be negative-.

Where depressions occur close to the pond, & will hold
water after the pond is formed, or where such places
hold water at time of low lake level, when practical
they should be connected to the pond by ditches facing down stream to
allow fish access to them-

Remove from ponds & swamps near the lake & in the
drainage valley where practical all bull rushes, ( ),
( ), ( ), and such other acquatic growth as may become
an expensive nuisance if transported into the lake-

It would be adva a marked advantage to
Build dam as high as essential & obtain
previous consent of the authorities to use flash
boards for mosquito control exclusively-.
Also so far as practical to obtain written permit for
allowing of marked fuctuations when necessary for purposes of malaria
control-

20 After such of the precautions above mentioned
as are practical have been carried out and
the water in the lake brought to its final level-
there may yet be some additional work to
do which if neglected may cause the power
plant owners considerable unnecessary
expenditure-.

21 Certain classes of acquatic vegetation such
as ( ) may appear in the pond & a sharp
lookout should be kept so as to remove such
plants that protect mosquito larvae from wind
drifting, from fish & other natural enemies and
they should all be removed at once while their
eradication is a question of a few dollars expendi-
ture rather than hundreds of dollars or thousands
later on-. They may originate up stream or be
introduced by other means-

Hammocks of logs, collections of vegetable debris,
& fallen trees etc that will collect floating debris
& afford larvae protection should be removed in
the early spring and at proper intervals during
the anopheles breeding season-

Certain parts of some inlets within anopheles
flight distance of habitations or inhabited areas
may need to have the banks kept free of grasses
that lean over into the water- Some steep banks
against which vegetation lodges may need
the removal of debris collecting at their base,
from time to time when anopheles larvae
are present- In some instances it is advisable
to have use floating booms, similar to a log boom
but made of saplings & anchored close to shore in order
to keepmaintain an oil film of about three feet in width
parallel to the shore line between the boom & shore line
at the prolific production area-

In inlets and sections where there is a tendency
for algae (spirogyra) to farm, inexpensive treatment
with copper sulphate will generally prove
satisfactory-.
